Award.AwardTitle: NRT-IGE: Innovating Graduate STEM Education Through Bio-Social Partnerships

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
NRT-IGE: Innovating Graduate STEM Education Through Bio-Social Partnerships

Distinct barriers of communication exist between the social sciences and the biological or life sciences in the academy. Scholars from each are trained to produce knowledge from a discipline-specific perspective, and seldom have the opportunity, as students, to engage in cross-disciplinary inquiry. This National Science Foundation Research Traineeship (NRT) award in the Innovations in Graduate Education (IGE) Track to Temple University brings together scientists from the departments of Geography and Urban Studies (Social Sciences) and Biology (Life Sciences) to pilot a model for cross-disciplinary learning and communication that will use studios as a collaborative learning space and a science museum as a venue for public communication. The project will contribute to wider academic reflection about the production of body-centered knowledge and the role of university partnerships to share this knowledge.

The goal of the project is to prepare graduate students in the social and life sciences to communicate with each other and with the public by focusing on one broad commonality - the drive to produce knowledge about the human body. The body is a complex phenomenon that is simultaneously biological and social, and thus represents a strategic thematic focus for interdisciplinary collaboration. The model of interdisciplinary graduate education to be developed and tested will use the design studio approach, which asks students to structure inquiry around an ill-defined problem. Graduate student learning will be organized around two sequential design studios and an interactive exhibit. This series is sequential in that each stage demands a broader audience around which to focus design problems. Students in the first studio will design for intra-classroom communication; while in the second studio, they will design for outside audiences and receive feedback from students in middle school, high school, and undergraduate classrooms. Prototypes developed in the design studios will be transformed into exhibits to be presented to public audiences at the Franklin Institute, a science museum in Philadelphia, PA. Student learning will be tracked and evaluated, as will the impacts of outreach activities on students and families. As such, the project seeks to collect data on the effectiveness of this model for interdisciplinary graduate education and university-museum partnerships that could be more broadly scaled and adapted.

The NSF Research Traineeship (NRT) Program is designed to encourage the development and implementation of bold, new, potentially transformative, and scalable models for STEM graduate education training. The Innovations in Graduate Education Track is dedicated solely to piloting, testing, and evaluating novel, innovative, and potentially transformative approaches to graduate education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project tested a studio model for interdisciplinary graduate-level research training between the social sciences and life sciences. Design studios, much like those common in architecture, provide students with a common space to problem-solve interactively and iteratively. The project developed the Bio-Social Studio with a focus on the human body to form teams across disciplinary and epistemological divides in the social and life sciences. Graduate student teams chose their own problems to advance, each of which was intentionally “fuzzy” or ill-defined and related to the human body, its health, and/or wellbeing. Students worked in teams from conceptual models, then to 2D and 3D designs and, ultimately, to exhibit prototypes. These deliverables were critiqued and improved upon, becoming interactive exhibits facilitated by our students at Philadelphia’s science museum, The Franklin Institute.

 

The project assessed the studio model through observations of the studio courses, as well as faculty logs, focus groups with students, artifacts, and exit interviews. A central finding was that due to the unfamiliarity of working in a design studio, the studio work disoriented participating graduate students, pushing them out of disciplinary comforts, while at the same time providing them positions of authority from which to contribute to their team’s problem-solving. This process demanded creativity from student teams as they learned to think together. In this way, the Bio-Social Studio model shows noteworthy potential to co-train scholars from life and social sciences to generate novel questions and convergence thinking. Moreover, the studio’s emphasis on convergence thinking and synthesis provided an agenda and context for student and faculty participants to recognize the value of epistemic flexibility, and its critical importance to solving the problems at hand. Additionally, the student-led facilitation of exhibits in a museum setting offered important lessons in science communication with general audiences. Family participants demonstrated the potential for high-level science thinking, particularly with respect to social structures and social relationships. The assessment of the exhibits through observations and interviews suggested that focusing on bio-social aspects of the human body (e.g., stress or pleasure) may provide avenues to integrate valuable aspects of social learning into science about the human body. 

 

Finally, in addition to these pedagogical findings, the project made significant advances in the theories and concepts that underlie bio-social science. While bio-social science has had a long history, new directions and recent technological advancements have made important ethical and analytical changes to this field. Still, bio-social science lacks a framework for working critically and collectively across epistemological divides, or different ways of knowing. Students and faculty in the Bio-Social Studio developed an epistemologically flexible framework for understanding the intersection biological, biographical, and biospheric elements of human life. This new framework, dubbed Bio3Science, centers knowledge about the human body at the level of the individual, where the body’s dense, dynamic interconnections with the world can be understood as unique, even as they are ever-changing. This framework can be used to understand many diverse conditions and diseases in the body, and can be used as a means to ensure collaborative hypothesis-building in research teams that cross epistemological and disciplinary divides.
